study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the clinical presentation, evolution of epilepsy, and biological mechanisms of epileptogenesis in Menkes disease, as well as the effects of copper supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that epilepsy in Menkes disease progresses through distinct stages, with copper supplementation showing benefits in patients with residual ATP7A activity. Molecular disruptions in copper-dependent pathways contribute to neuronal excitability and epileptogenesis.
population_specificity: Patients with Menkes disease (an X-linked recessive neurodegenerative disorder).
effective_dosage: Subcutaneous cupric chloride supplementation (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine if 12 months of copper supplementation would improve functional activities of daily living (ADLs) in patients with copper deficiency.
results_summary: Barthel Index (BI) scores significantly improved after 12 months of copper supplementation, indicating better functional ADLs. A significant inverse correlation was found between symptom duration before treatment and BI score improvement.
population_specificity: 15 consecutively diagnosed patients with copper deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between diets high in copper (Cu) and iron (Fe) and cognitive decline or Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: The study found no clear evidence of a beneficial effect of Cu supplementation or depletion on cognitive performance in AD patients. Elevated Cu levels in serum were observed, but brain and cerebrospinal fluid levels were mostly unchanged. High dietary Cu, especially with saturated fatty acids (SFA), was associated with cognitive decline.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals, particularly those at risk of or diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease.
interactions: High intake of saturated fatty acids (SFA) may interact with dietary Cu to increase cognitive decline risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare serum copper concentrations between patients on long-term gastrostomy and jejunostomy feeding and assess the effectiveness of cocoa supplementation for treating copper deficiency.
results_summary: Copper levels significantly decreased in the jejunostomy group after 6 months, leading to severe deficiency in some patients. Cocoa powder supplementation (1.36-2.56 mg copper daily) successfully treated the deficiency.
population_specificity: Patients on long-term enteral tube feeding (36 gastrostomy, 23 jejunostomy).
effective_dosage: 10-40 g cocoa powder daily (equivalent to 1.36-2.56 mg copper).
study_duration: More than one year of enteral feeding, with supplementation duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increased Copper (Cu) and Zinc (Zn) intakes would reduce the risk of bone loss in postmenopausal women with adequate vitamin D and Calcium (Ca) intake.
results_summary: The study found that Cu and Zn supplementation led to the greatest decreases in bone mineral content, densities, and T scores. However, Zn supplementation appeared beneficial for bone health only in women with usual Zn intakes < 8.0 mg/d, while higher Zn intakes had a negative effect.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 51-80 years with adequate vitamin D and Ca intake.
effective_dosage: 2 mg Cu and 12 mg Zn daily, alongside 600 mg Ca.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare serum copper (Cu) levels in acute leukemia patients versus healthy controls to assess potential associations with the disease.
results_summary: The study found that serum copper levels were significantly elevated in acute leukemia patients compared to healthy controls (p=0.003), suggesting a possible link between higher copper levels and the disease.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed acute leukemia patients (n=42) and healthy controls matched for socioeconomic status and eating habits (n=40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether zinc supplementation (not copper) affected ADHD symptoms and whether it influenced the optimal dose of amphetamine in children with ADHD.
results_summary: The study found that zinc supplementation (30 mg/day) reduced the optimal amphetamine dose by 37%, but other clinical outcomes were inconsistent. Copper and iron blood indices were not impaired by zinc supplementation.
population_specificity: American children aged 6-14 with DSM-IV ADHD.
effective_dosage: 15 mg once daily or 15 mg twice daily (30 mg/day) as zinc glycinate.
study_duration: 13 weeks (8 weeks monotherapy, 5 weeks with added amphetamine).
interactions: None mentioned for copper. Zinc reduced the required amphetamine dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dietary almond supplementation on serum lipid levels and their relation to copper-induced lipid oxidation parameters in men with mild hyperlipidemia.
results_summary: Almond supplementation significantly reduced LDL cholesterol, total cholesterol, and apo-B100. It also altered the relationship between lipid risk factors and susceptibility to oxidative modification, with correlations observed between lipid oxidation parameters and cholesterol levels.
population_specificity: 30 healthy volunteer men (aged 45.57 ± 7.14 years, BMI 24.29 ± 2.15 kg/m²) with mild hyperlipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether antioxidant supplementation, including Copper, could reduce oxidative stress and improve platelet membrane fluidity in patients with idiopathic retinal periphlebitis (Eales' disease).
results_summary: The study found that antioxidant supplementation, which included Copper, significantly decreased oxidative stress (measured by TBARS levels) and improved platelet membrane fluidity in patients with Eales' disease.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic retinal periphlebitis (Eales' disease) and healthy controls.
effective_dosage: Copper 2 mg once daily as part of a combined antioxidant preparation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a lifestyle intervention trial could affect the dietary intake of copper (Cu) among other trace elements and magnesium in dysmetabolic adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant baseline differences in copper intake between intervention and control groups. The intervention group did not show a significant change in copper intake, while the control group reduced their intake of zinc and chromium but not copper.
population_specificity: 335 dysmetabolic adults (169 in intervention group, 166 in control group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess acute and chronic cellular responses to mild-to-moderate copper changes in healthy individuals by measuring copper and iron content, and MT2A and TfR mRNA abundance after copper challenge.
results_summary: Cells from copper-supplemented individuals showed greater copper content increases, especially at higher concentrations (20 μM Cu), with significant differences by treatment and time. MT2A mRNA levels paralleled copper changes, while iron content and TfR mRNA responses were inconsistent.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of zinc supplementation on plasma copper concentrations and related metabolic markers in competitive athletes.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation (22 mg/day) for 30 days decreased plasma copper levels and increased the Zn:Cu ratio, but had no effect on thyroid hormones. A delayed increase in fasting insulin and HOMA2-IR was observed after zinc discontinuation, suggesting potential impairment of glucose utilization.
population_specificity: Competitive cyclists (n=7, aged 32±8 years).
study_duration: 30 days of zinc supplementation, followed by 30 days of placebo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between zinc supplementation and copper deficiency, focusing on zinc's role in cytotoxicity and its impact on human health.
results_summary: The study found that long-term, high-dose zinc supplementation interferes with copper uptake, leading to copper deficiency, which can have toxic effects. Zinc deficiency, rather than intoxication, poses a more common risk to human health, affecting growth, neuronal development, and immunity.
population_specificity: General human health, with implications for those with malnutrition, aging, certain diseases, or deregulated homeostasis.
interactions: Zinc supplementation interferes with copper uptake.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the potential role of metals, including copper, in cognitive impairment and their interaction with aluminum in Alzheimer's disease pathogenesis.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that copper, along with other elements in drinking water, could influence cognitive impairment or modify aluminum neurotoxicity, but no specific findings about copper's effects are detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of Alzheimer's disease risk factors).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify micronutrient deficiencies, including copper, in patients after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery patients are at risk for copper deficiency post-surgery, necessitating lifelong supplementation with multivitamin and multitrace mineral supplements. Copper deficiency was highlighted as a concern alongside other trace minerals like iron, selenium, and zinc.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Lifelong supplementation recommended, with monitoring starting at 3 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multi-micronutrient supplement containing copper, among other nutrients, could reduce the duration of hospitalization in HIV-infected children with diarrhea or pneumonia.
results_summary: The study found that the multi-micronutrient supplement, including copper, significantly reduced the duration of hospitalization for both diarrhea and pneumonia in HIV-infected children, with no reported adverse effects. Anthropometric indices and micronutrient concentrations did not differ between supplemented and placebo groups.
population_specificity: HIV-infected children aged 4-24 months hospitalized with diarrhea or pneumonia.
effective_dosage: Levels based on recommended daily allowances (exact amounts not specified).
study_duration: Until discharge from the hospital (average duration: 7.3 days for supplemented group, 9.0 days for placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether zinc supplementation affects hemoglobin concentrations in children, indirectly assessing potential copper-related anemia risks.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation (10-20 mg/d) did not significantly alter hemoglobin concentrations in children, suggesting no adverse effect on iron transport via copper absorption. Some benefits might exist for severely anemic or zinc-deficient children, warranting further study.
population_specificity: Apparently healthy children aged 0-15 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review case reports of copper deficiency myelopathy (CDM) to understand its demographics, causes, clinical presentation, and treatment outcomes.
results_summary: CDM was linked to risk factors like gastrointestinal surgery, zinc overload, and malabsorption, often presenting with cytopenias and abnormal spinal MRI. Copper supplementation improved hematological and neurological outcomes, though neurological recovery was partial.
population_specificity: Patients with copper deficiency myelopathy, predominantly women in their fifth and sixth decades.
interactions: Zinc overload was noted to impair copper absorption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of multivitamin/mineral supplementation, including copper, on trace element levels in serum and follicular fluid of women undergoing IVF.
results_summary: The study found that copper levels in follicular fluid were lower in IVF patients compared to controls, but supplementation normalized these levels. No adverse effects of copper were reported.
population_specificity: Women undergoing IVF (n=30 in the supplemented group, n=13 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the importance of copper (Cu) during pregnancy and lactation, its deficiency risks, and the mechanisms by which Cu deficiency affects fetal and neonatal development.
results_summary: The study found that copper is critical for fetal and neonatal development, with deficiencies leading to severe adverse effects in multiple organs and systems. Even postnatal Cu supplementation may not fully reverse developmental deficits caused by prenatal deficiency.
population_specificity: Pregnant and lactating women, fetuses, neonates, and individuals with conditions predisposing to Cu deficiency (e.g., Menkes disease, bariatric surgery patients).
interactions: Excessive zinc or iron intake, certain drugs, and bariatric surgery can induce secondary Cu deficiencies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mutant SOD1 proteins compete with cytochrome c oxidase (Cytox) for mitochondrial copper, leading to Cytox inactivation and cell death in familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (fALS).
results_summary: Mutant SOD1s induced cell death and decreased Cytox activity without affecting Cytox subunit II protein levels, unlike copper depletion. NO scavengers or NOS inhibitors prevented Cytox inhibition and restored cell viability, suggesting NO involvement in mutant SOD1-induced mitochondrial toxicity.
population_specificity: Mouse motoneuronal neuroblastoma x spinal cord cell line-34 cells expressing wild-type or mutant human SOD1s.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how clioquinol (CQ) affects copper, iron, and zinc homeostasis in yeast and mammalian cells, particularly its role in metal regulation and enzyme activity.
results_summary: CQ induced metal sequestration at the cellular membrane, causing cytosolic metal depletion despite overall accumulation. It increased SOD1 activity by enhancing Ccs1's access to CQ-bound copper, while reducing activity of other metal-sensitive enzymes.
population_specificity: Yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) and mammalian cell line (SH-SY5Y).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute copper administration affects iron absorption in healthy adult women.
results_summary: The study found that copper administration in aqueous solution did not inhibit iron bioavailability, with varying Cu/Fe molar ratios showing no significant difference in iron absorption. Results support that divalent metal transporter 1 is not physiologically relevant for copper absorption in humans.
population_specificity: 29 healthy adult women
effective_dosage: 0.5 mg Fe with Cu/Fe molar ratios of 0.5:1, 1:1, 2:1 (Study I) or 4:1, 6:1, 8:1 (Study II), administered as an aqueous solution on days 1, 2, 14, and 15.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and investigate the underlying mechanism of Cordyceps militaris (CM) in treating chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: CM significantly alleviated COPD by improving lung function, inhibiting pulmonary inflammation, regulating amino acid metabolism, ameliorating gut microbiota imbalance, and increasing short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs).
population_specificity: COPD mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the biological roles of copper, its homeostatic regulation, and its therapeutic potential in diseases like Menkes and Wilson disorders, neurodegenerative conditions, and cancer.
results_summary: Copper is essential for enzyme function and redox reactions but requires strict regulation to avoid toxicity. Copper chelation therapy is effective for Menkes and Wilson diseases and shows promise in treating neurodegenerative disorders and cancer by inhibiting angiogenesis and inducing apoptosis. Elevated copper levels are linked to various cancers, and copper complexes are being studied as potential antitumor agents.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of copper's role in human biology and disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of Cordyceps sinensis extract (CSE) and its potential mechanisms in regulating inflammation.
results_summary: CSE significantly inhibited pro-inflammatory cytokine secretion, reduced inflammation-related protein MMP9, and upregulated the anti-inflammatory Nrf2/HO-1 pathway. It also mitigated oxidative stress-induced inflammation and protected cells from inflammatory damage.
population_specificity: THP-1 and BEAS-2B cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study how Fermented Cordyceps Powder (FCP) alleviates inflammation and fibrosis in silicosis by examining macrophage polarization and the HMGB1-TLR4-NF-κB pathway.
results_summary: FCP reduced M1 and M2 macrophage polarization and HMGB1 expression in silicosis rats, while FCP-containing serum reduced silica-induced inflammation and fibrosis in cell models. Suppression of HMGB1 notably decreased M1 polarization but had no significant effect on M2 polarization.
population_specificity: Silicosis rat models and co-culture cell models (NR8383 and RFL-6 cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the proteome profiles of fresh Cordyceps sinensis under different drying conditions to understand how drying methods affect its biochemical properties.
results_summary: The study identified 3762 proteins, showing variations between fresh and dried samples, with vacuum freeze-drying causing the fewest protein changes. Drying methods significantly altered protein content and metabolic pathways, suggesting potential impacts on nutritional and medicinal value.
population_specificity: Cordyceps sinensis samples (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Cordyceps sinensis could protect against renal injury induced by low-dose contrast medium during coronary computed tomography angiography (CCTA) and evaluated its efficacy using functional MRI.
results_summary: Cordyceps sinensis showed potential protective effects on renal function in Beagle dogs undergoing CCTA, with significant changes in renal function parameters and MRI metrics observed in some groups. The combination of IVIM and BOLD MRI provided a reliable non-invasive method to assess these effects.
population_specificity: Beagle dogs with induced renal insufficiency

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cordyceps militaris ARA301 extract (CME) could prevent lung injury induced by LPS in mice.
results_summary: CME administration reduced immune cell infiltration, tissue fibrosis, mucus deposition, and pro-inflammatory cytokine production in LPS-induced lung injury. It also suppressed key inflammatory markers (MUC5AC, iNOS, COX-2) and inhibited phosphorylation of inflammatory signaling proteins (p65, IκBα, IKKα).
population_specificity: Mice with LPS-induced lung injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the alleviating effect and mechanism of Cordyceps militaris solid medium extract (CMME) on acute lung injury (ALI) in mice, focusing on gut microbiota and metabolomics.
results_summary: CMME improved pulmonary injury, reduced inflammation and oxidative stress, decreased macrophage activation and neutrophil recruitment, increased gut microbiota diversity, and reversed metabolic disturbances linked to purine, nucleotide, and bile acid metabolism.
population_specificity: LPS-induced ALI mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chitosan nanoparticles (CNPs) could enhance the bioactivity and stability of Cordyceps militaris grown on germinated Rhynchosia nulubilis (GRC) and effectively deliver it to target tissues to mitigate PM2.5-induced lung damage.
results_summary: The study found that GRC encapsulated with CNPs (GCN) significantly reduced lung injury, restored lung epithelial barrier integrity, and alleviated oxidative stress in PM2.5-exposed mice and A549 cells, demonstrating improved efficacy compared to GRC alone.
population_specificity: PM2.5-exposed mice and A549 human lung epithelial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how Cordyceps cicadae polysaccharide (CCP) regulates intestinal microbiota, protects the intestinal mucosal barrier, and reduces inflammation in a mouse model of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: CCP treatment increased beneficial gut bacteria, restored microbial diversity, reduced endotoxin and proinflammatory cytokines, and improved antioxidant capacity by modulating the TLR4/NF-κB signaling pathway. It also enhanced intestinal barrier function by upregulating tight junction proteins.
population_specificity: Mice with streptozotocin-induced type 2 diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Cordyceps polysaccharide (CPS) combined with moxifloxacin (MXF) on intestinal barrier damage caused by abdominal infection under simulated microgravity conditions.
results_summary: The combination of MXF and CPS effectively mitigated intestinal barrier damage in rats exposed to microgravity, improving ultrastructural and pathological impairments, increasing key intestinal barrier proteins (MUC2 and RegIII α/γ), and modulating immune responses by reducing proinflammatory cytokines and altering immune cell frequencies.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to simulated microgravity and abdominal infection via cecal ligation and puncture (CLP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential and mechanism of Cordyceps militaris in combating Fatty Liver Disease (FLD), particularly in inhibiting hepatocyte apoptosis.
results_summary: Cordyceps militaris demonstrated protective effects against palmitic acid-induced hepatocyte damage in vitro and attenuated FLD progression in mice by reducing body weight gain, improving fasting blood glucose levels, and mitigating liver fibrosis, ER stress, inflammation, and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Clone9 hepatocytes (in vitro) and FVB mice fed a NASH diet (in vivo).
effective_dosage: Not specified (powdered CM administered orally in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical effectiveness of Cordyceps sinensis as an adjuvant therapy for renal dysfunction, particularly acute kidney injury, through a meta-analysis of existing studies.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that Cordyceps sinensis improved renal function by reducing blood creatinine levels, shortening the oliguria period, and increasing urine osmolality, with higher efficacy observed in northern Chinese patients. The summary receiver operating characteristic (SROC) curve showed an AUC of 0.88, indicating good prognostic accuracy.
population_specificity: Patients with renal dysfunction, including acute kidney injury (1,310 participants across 15 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidepressant-like effects of a combined Cordyceps militaris and Armillaria mellea formula, focusing on neurotransmitter regulation and immunomodulation via microglia.
results_summary: The CM-AM formula prevented stress-induced abnormal behaviors, reduced monoamine turnover, lowered corticosterone levels, and modulated microglia activation by balancing pro- and anti-inflammatory proteins in the hippocampus.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to chronic stress (UCMS protocols).
effective_dosage: Low-dose, medium-dose, and high-dose formulations (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the compatibility of Cordyceps javanica strains with common chemical pesticides and their combined insecticidal effects against Myzus persicae.
results_summary: The study found that Cordyceps javanica strains showed good compatibility with acetamiprid and some compatibility with avermectin and imidacloprid, while fungicide compatibility was highest with kasugamycin. The combination of C. javanica IJ-tg19 with acetamiprid resulted in higher insecticidal rates compared to using the fungus or pesticide alone.
population_specificity: Myzus persicae (aphids) and Cordyceps javanica strains IF-1106 and IJ-tg19.
effective_dosage: 1 × 10³ to 1 × 10⁷ spores/mL for C. javanica IJ-tg19.
interactions: Interactions noted with chemical pesticides (avermectin, imidacloprid, acetamiprid, chlorothalonil, boscalid, kasugamycin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance polysaccharide content by fusing P. florida and C. militaris and explore their antioxidant and antibacterial potential.
results_summary: The hybrids showed superior growth, increased biomass, and metabolite production, with higher exopolysaccharide concentrations and novel bioactive compounds linked to enhanced antimicrobial and antioxidant activities.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of Cordyceps as a treatment for sepsis, focusing on its anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antibacterial properties.
results_summary: Studies indicate that Cordyceps extract and bioactive compounds target oxidative and nitrosative stress, reduce inflammation, and modulate the immune system, which are critical in sepsis. The extract may also protect organs like the brain, liver, kidneys, lungs, and heart during sepsis.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the signaling mechanisms behind the anti-inflammatory effects of EPS-LM, an exopolysaccharide from Cordyceps sinensis, in LPS-stimulated macrophages.
results_summary: EPS-LM significantly reduced pro-inflammatory mediators (NO, ROS), suppressed TLR4 and MyD88 expression, delayed NF-κB translocation, and inhibited TLR4-MyD88 binding, demonstrating multifaceted anti-inflammatory and oxidative stress-reducing effects.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 macrophage cell culture (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Cordyceps militaris extract (CM) and cordycepin on adipogenesis and lipolysis in obesity.
results_summary: CM and cordycepin reduced lipid accumulation in 3T3-L1 cells and lowered serum LDL/VLDL levels in diabetic obese mice, while also reducing oxidative stress and cell senescence markers.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 cells and diabetic obese mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the inhibitory effects of Cordyceps militaris aqueous extract on Candida albicans infections and its immune-modulating properties in Galleria mellonella larvae.
results_summary: The aqueous extract of C. militaris prolonged the survival of larvae infected with C. albicans, increased hemocyte counts, and upregulated immune-related genes, demonstrating protective effects against infection.
population_specificity: Larvae of the greater wax moth (Galleria mellonella).
study_duration: Observations were made at 1, 24, and 48 hours post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review advancements in the immunomodulatory effects of Cordyceps polysaccharides, focusing on their potential therapeutic applications.
results_summary: Cordyceps polysaccharides enhance immune cell activity (macrophages, lymphocytes, dendritic cells) and increase immune-active substances like cytokines and chemokines. Animal studies confirmed their ability to counteract immune suppression, improve immune organ indices, and reduce tumor-induced immune evasion.
population_specificity: Primarily animal models and in vitro studies; human specificity not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which Cordyceps militaris extract (CME) or cordycepin (CPN) supplementation ameliorates LPS-induced acute liver injury in piglets.
results_summary: CPN or CME supplementation significantly reduced C-reactive protein levels, improved liver tissue pathology, and modulated immune-related genes and metabolites, attenuating LPS-induced acute liver injury. Multi-omics analysis identified specific pathways and metabolites associated with liver protection.
population_specificity: Weaned piglets (n=24, divided into 4 groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the ethnopharmacology, therapeutic potential, and conservation challenges of Cordyceps sinensis.
results_summary: The study highlights Cordyceps sinensis's potential for treating chronic ailments with minimal side effects but notes overexploitation threatens its survival. It also discusses conservation practices and market dynamics.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cordyceps polysaccharide (CP) could improve metabolic and reproductive dysfunction in PCOS by modulating gut microbiota and suppressing inflammatory pathways.
results_summary: CP improved polycystic ovarian lesions, regulated hormone levels, and restored the estrous cycle in PCOS rats. It also modulated glucose-lipid metabolism, reduced gut-derived LPS, and suppressed the TLR4/MyD88/NF-κB inflammatory pathway, improving insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Female rats with induced polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect and mechanism of Cordyceps cicadae polysaccharides (CCP) on ameliorating pulmonary fibrosis in a silicosis mouse model.
results_summary: CCP reduced fibrosis-related indicators and pro-inflammatory factors in lung tissue, improving inflammation and fibrosis by inhibiting TGF-β1/Smad and TLR4/NF-κB pathways. Medium and high doses of CCP showed significant improvements in body weight, lung coefficient, and fibrosis markers compared to the model group.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice with induced silicosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of wild Cordyceps sinensis on chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in rats, focusing on metabolic and biochemical changes.
results_summary: Cordyceps sinensis modulated glycerophospholipid, glutathione, and tryptophan metabolism, reduced oxidative stress (lower MDA and GSSG, higher SOD and GSH), and decreased inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-8, MMP-9), improving lung tissue damage in COPD rats.
population_specificity: COPD-induced rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of cordycepin and C. militaris ethanolic extract (Cm-EE) on sensitizing cancer cells and regulating immune responses against breast cancer (BC) and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cells.
results_summary: Cordycepin decreased HLA-ABC-positive cells in pre-treated cancer cells, while Cm-EE increased NKG2D ligand and death receptor expression. Cordycepin also enhanced NKG2D receptor and death ligand expression on immune cells, and Cm-EE stimulated IL-2, IL-6, and IL-10 production, leading to elevated cancer cell death when co-cultured with immune cells.
population_specificity: Breast cancer (BC) and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cells in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of Bailing capsule (Cordyceps sinensis preparation) compared to a placebo in managing chronic bronchitis symptoms.
results_summary: Bailing capsule significantly reduced the frequency of acute exacerbations of chronic bronchitis and improved symptom severity (expectoration and wheezing) compared to placebo, with no significant difference in adverse events between groups.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic bronchitis from eight hospitals in China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism by which Cordyceps guangdongensis polysaccharides (CGP) improve high-fat diet-induced metabolic diseases, including obesity and related disorders.
results_summary: CGP reduced fat mass, improved blood lipid levels and hepatic damage, restored gut microbiota dysbiosis, and regulated metabolic disorders by altering bile acid composition and influencing lipid and carbohydrate metabolism pathways. Specific gut bacteria (Odoribacter, Bifidobacterium, and Bi. pseudolongum) were negatively correlated with fat and blood lipid indicators.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced metabolic disease model (not specified if human or animal, but likely animal based on context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate a novel antibiotic (cordysetin A) derived from Cordyceps militaris for its potential in treating tuberculosis, particularly against multidrug-resistant strains.
results_summary: The study identified cordysetin A as a promising anti-tuberculosis agent with significant in vitro and in vivo activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis and low cytotoxicity. The d-configuration of the amino acid in the compound was found to be crucial for its efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo models, likely preclinical).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute, sub-acute toxicity, and genotoxicity profiles of Cordyceps militaris methanolic extract in Swiss albino mice to assess its safety for medicinal use.
results_summary: The study found no significant toxicity at doses up to 2000 mg/kg, with minor hematological and biochemical changes, mild renal toxicity, and notable improvements in seminal parameters like sperm concentration and testosterone levels.
population_specificity: Swiss albino mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the inhibitory effects of Cordyceps militaris extract (CME) and cordycepin on hyperuricemia (HUA) in mice, focusing on uric acid-lowering mechanisms and gut microbiome changes.
results_summary: CME and cordycepin effectively lowered uric acid levels by inhibiting xanthine oxidase activity, reducing xanthine precursors, and improving insulin resistance. Treatment also altered gut microbiome composition, decreasing specific bacterial species.
population_specificity: Potassium oxyzinate-induced hyperuricemic mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective role of Cordyceps cicadae and its active ingredient Myriocin (Myr) against Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) by studying its effects on retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) cells and related signaling pathways.
results_summary: Myr was identified as an active ingredient in C. cicadae and demonstrated protective effects on RPE cells, reducing structural damage and cell death induced by sodium iodate. It also restored retinal structure and function in AMD mice by modulating the TNF-RIPK1/RIPK3/MLKL signaling pathway.
population_specificity: In vitro (ARPE-19 cells) and in vivo (AMD mice) models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Cordyceps militaris on growth performance and intestinal epithelium functions in weaned pigs.
results_summary: Cordyceps militaris improved growth performance, nutrient digestibility, antioxidant capacity, intestinal health, and beneficial gut microbiota in weaned pigs. It also enhanced tight-junction protein expression and functional gene activity in the intestines.
population_specificity: Weaned pigs (180 pigs, 6 per pen, 5 treatment groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-SARS-CoV-2 potential of Cordyceps militaris through pharmacoinformatic analysis and in-vitro assays.
results_summary: Molecular docking showed Cordycepin had the highest affinity to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. The aqueous extract reduced viral copy numbers by 50.24% at 100 μg/mL.
population_specificity: In-vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the chemical elements, pharmacological effects, clinical application, and drug safety of Cordyceps in treating ischemic cardio-cerebrovascular diseases (CCVDs).
results_summary: Cordyceps and its bioactive components showed potential in protecting against cerebral and myocardial ischemic/reperfusion injuries by improving blood perfusion, reducing oxidative damage, suppressing inflammation, preventing apoptosis, and promoting tissue regeneration. It also positively influenced factors like hypertension, thrombosis, atherosclerosis, and arrhythmia.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant capacity and protective effects of peptides from Cordyceps militaris cultivated with tussah pupa (ECPs) on H2O2-injured HepG2 cells.
results_summary: The study found that low molecular weight peptides (ECP1) exhibited strong antioxidant activity, improved cell survival rates, reduced apoptosis, decreased ROS levels and MDA content, and increased CAT and GSH-Px activities in HepG2 cells. Enzymatic hydrolysis altered peptide structure and increased hydrophobic and acidic amino acids, suggesting potential value for cosmetics and health food.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (a human liver cancer cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects and pharmacological mechanisms of Bailing Capsule (containing Cordyceps) in treating chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that Bailing Capsule reduced renal function indicators (24UP, BUN, Scr) and inflammatory markers (hs-CRP, IL-6, TNF-α) compared to controls, suggesting multi-target and multi-pathway therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the physicochemical properties, antioxidant capacities, and effects of Cordyceps militaris polysaccharides (CMPs) on ulcerative colitis (UC) in zebrafish and oxidative damage in RAW 264.7 cells.
results_summary: The study found differences in monosaccharide composition among the polysaccharides, with CFEPs showing higher antioxidant capacity. CFIPs significantly reduced oxidative stress markers and improved UC by activating the MyD88/NF-κB pathway.
population_specificity: Zebrafish (UC model) and RAW 264.7 cells (oxidative damage model).
study_duration: 3 days for CFIPs treatment in zebrafish.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of wild Cordyceps proteins (WCPs) on gut microbiota and immune system function in MRL/lpr mice, a model for lupus nephritis.
results_summary: WCP increased CD4+ cells, reduced proinflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6), improved intestinal barrier proteins (ZO-1, Claudin-1, Occludin), altered gut microbiota (higher Firmicutes/Bacteroidetes ratio), and suppressed the MAPK/NF-кB pathway in lupus nephritis mice.
population_specificity: MRL/lpr mice (a lupus-prone strain).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 2'-deoxyadenosine, a major active component in Cordyceps sinensis, could ameliorate acute kidney injury (AKI) by regulating natural killer (NK) cell activity.
results_summary: High doses of 2'-deoxyadenosine significantly alleviated renal damage in vivo by inhibiting NK cell activity, reducing perforin and IFN-γ release, and suppressing the STING/IRF3 pathway. The study suggests Cordyceps sinensis may mitigate AKI through immune modulation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo and in vitro models, likely animal or cell-based).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the absolute crystal structure of beauveriolide I using 3D electron diffraction.
results_summary: The study successfully determined the absolute structure of beauveriolide I, a cyclodepsipeptide, by overcoming previous challenges in crystal structure analysis through 3D electron diffraction. The compound crystallizes in space group I2 with specific lattice parameters.
population_specificity: Not applicable (structural study, no human or animal subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Cordyceps sinensis as an adjuvant treatment for lung cancer, focusing on tumor response, immune function, quality of life, and adverse reactions.
results_summary: The study found that Cordyceps improved tumor response rate, immune function (CD4, CD8, NK cells, IgA, IgG, IgM), quality of life (KPS), and reduced adverse drug reactions (myelosuppression, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia) and radiation pneumonitis. Some outcomes (liver/renal damage, gastrointestinal reactions) showed no significant difference.
population_specificity: 928 patients with lung cancer across 12 randomized clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of non-lethal doses of fungicides on the circadian clock protein CmFRQ and fruiting body morphology in two strains of Cordyceps militaris.
results_summary: Fungicide treatment altered CmFRQ expression in both strains, with varying effects on fruiting body degeneration or rejuvenation after fungicide removal, indicating morphological diversity. The changes in CmFRQ levels persisted post-treatment, suggesting lasting impacts on the circadian clock.
population_specificity: Cordyceps militaris strains TN and CmFRQ-454.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the anticancer potential of methanolic extracts from cultivated Cordyceps militaris fruiting bodies against Dalton's Lymphoma Ascites (DLA) cells in vitro.
results_summary: The methanolic extract induced apoptosis in DLA cells, evidenced by membrane blebbing, chromatin condensation, and nuclei fragmentation. Molecular docking simulations suggested interactions with antiapoptotic proteins, supporting its cytotoxic effects.
population_specificity: In vitro study using Dalton's Lymphoma Ascites (DLA) cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Cordyceps cicadae could alleviate inflammatory responses, oxidative stress, and fibrosis in lupus nephritis (LN) by targeting the PI3K/mTOR-mediated autophagy pathway.
results_summary: Cordyceps cicadae improved renal lesions, reduced inflammatory and oxidative stress damage, and inhibited fibrosis in MRL/lpr mice with LN. It also downregulated fibrosis biomarkers and involved the PI3K/mTOR-mediated autophagy pathway, though its effects were negated by a PI3K agonist.
population_specificity: MRL/lpr mice (a lupus-prone mouse model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the neuroprotective mechanisms and safety profile of Cordyceps extracts/bioactives for potential therapeutic use in neurodegenerative disorders.
results_summary: Cordyceps bioactives demonstrated antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anti-apoptotic activities, showing beneficial effects in managing neurodegenerative disorders in vitro and in vivo, though clinical trial data remain limited.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the production of cordycepin and its derivatives (adenine and adenosine) in Cordyceps militaris using various grain combinations in solid-state fermentation.
results_summary: Grain combinations 2, 7, 8, and 9 yielded higher cordycepin content than the control (rice), with combination 7 also showing significantly higher adenine content. The highest cordycepin content was achieved with a mix of rice, wheat, jowar, bajra, and sugarcane bagasse.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using Cordyceps militaris).
effective_dosage: Not specified (measured in mg/g of substrate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of prophylactic treatment with Cordyceps militaris on ulcerative colitis (UC) symptoms and its potential mechanisms, including gut microbiota modulation and intestinal mucosal barrier repair.
results_summary: Cordyceps militaris powder effectively mitigated UC symptoms in DSS-injured mice, reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines, enhanced intestinal mucosal barrier integrity, and reshaped gut microbiota composition. It also regulated metabolic pathways and promoted the growth of beneficial bacteria like Lactobacillus in vitro.
population_specificity: DSS-injured mice and in vitro experiments using UC patients' fecal samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic and therapeutic potential of cordycepin (CRD) from Cordyceps militaris in diabetic nephropathy (DN) by examining its effects on oxidative stress, inflammation, and the miR-193b-5p/MCL-1 axis.
results_summary: CRD attenuated high glucose-induced cell damage, inflammation, and abnormal energy metabolism in HK-2 cells and DN mice by modulating the miR-193b-5p/MCL-1 axis, reducing oxidative stress, and improving renal histopathology.
population_specificity: Diabetic nephropathy mice and high glucose-treated HK-2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the protective effects of fermented cordyceps powder (FCP) against silicosis and explore its mechanism of action.
results_summary: FCP reduced inflammatory cell infiltration, decreased pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α, TGF-β1), and lowered fibrosis markers (collagen, α-SMA, FN) in silicosis rats. It also modulated Th1, Th17, and Th2 immune responses.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with silica-induced silicosis.
effective_dosage: 300 mg/kg and 600 mg/kg daily by intragastric gavage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the auto-dissemination efficacy of Cordyceps fumosorosea strain PFs-1 (Priority®) in controlling Tetranychus urticae populations through indirect contamination.
results_summary: The study found that Cordyceps fumosorosea significantly increased mortality in T. urticae, with higher mortality rates observed as the number of contaminated individuals increased. The median lethal time (LT50) decreased with more contaminated individuals, indicating enhanced biological control effectiveness.
population_specificity: Tetranychus urticae (spider mites)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a nanoemulsion containing Cordyceps militaris polysaccharide and sesame oil could effectively treat Candida albicans-induced vaginitis in a murine model.
results_summary: The nanoemulsion formulation showed superior physical properties and stability compared to emulsion, significantly reduced Candida colonization and vaginitis symptoms, and modulated immune responses and vaginal microflora.
population_specificity: Murine model (mice) with vaginal Candida infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Cordyceps capsules as an adjunct to standard treatment in patients with mild to moderate COVID-19 infection.
results_summary: Cordyceps showed a shorter time to clinical recovery in mild cases, improved chest X-ray findings, and significant biomarker changes, but no difference in moderate cases. Recovery rates increased over time, with 100% recovery by day 30.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate COVID-19 infection (SpO2 <94%, respiratory rate ≥24/min).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the field persistence and efficacy of Cordyceps javanica Wf GA17 against whiteflies with the commercial strain Apopka97, both alone and when combined with JMS stylet oil.
results_summary: Cordyceps javanica Wf GA17 showed higher control levels in some trials when combined with JMS oil, but efficacy was short-lived. Both fungal strains performed similarly, with conidia persisting better than blastospores, but overall field efficacy was limited.
population_specificity: Whiteflies (Bemisia tabaci) in cotton and vegetable crops.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hypoglycemic, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory effects of Cordyceps cicadae polysaccharides (CH-P) and their regulatory impact on gut microbiota and metabolites in diabetic mice.
results_summary: CH-P treatment showed significant hypoglycemic, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory effects, improved tissue damage, and modulated gut microbiota composition and metabolic pathways, particularly involving tryptophan. FMT confirmed microbial remodeling's role in improving glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity, though GLP-1 levels remained unaffected.
population_specificity: Diabetic mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nanobubble water (NBW) could enhance the lipid-reducing effects of Cordyceps extract and withaferin A in hepatic cells.
results_summary: Oxygen NBW synergistically improved the lipid-reducing effects of Cordyceps extract, decreasing lipid content by 29% compared to 22% without NBW. The study suggests NBW may enhance the efficacy of natural compounds like Cordyceps for NAFLD.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of Cordyceps militaris steroids in managing cytokine storm-related hyperinflammation in Covid-19 using network ethnopharmacological and structure-based drug design approaches.
results_summary: The study identified 5 out of 16 steroids in Cordyceps militaris that may target 11 pathological proteins involved in 17 inflammatory pathways, with specific steroids interacting with thrombin and the glucocorticoid receptor, suggesting potential anti-inflammatory effects in SARS-CoV-2 infection.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico study, no human or animal subjects mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the efficacy and mechanisms of Cordyceps sinensis in treating renal fibrosis and chronic kidney diseases (CKDs) through a review of five commercial medicines derived from its fermented mycelium.
results_summary: The review found that Cordyceps sinensis alleviates renal fibrosis by modulating TGF-β1 signaling, reducing inflammation, and improving renal function, with efficacy demonstrated in various animal models and in vitro studies. However, the study calls for further large-scale clinical trials to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Animal models and in vitro renal cells; human applications inferred from commercial medicines meeting national standards.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate cordycepin's inhibitory effect on oral cancer xenografts in nude mice and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Cordycepin treatment achieved a 56.09% tumor inhibition rate, induced tumor cell apoptosis, and altered the expression of apoptosis-related proteins (Bax, Bcl-2, GRP78, CHOP, caspase-12) without causing pathological changes in vital organs.
population_specificity: BALB/c nude mice bearing human tongue squamous cell carcinoma (TCA-8113) xenografts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the active components of aqueous Cordyceps cicadae extract (CCE) and determine its effects on hyaluronan synthesis in human skin fibroblasts, exploring the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: CCE exhibited excellent antioxidant activities, promoted hyaluronan synthesis in fibroblasts, and significantly upregulated HA synthase 2 (HAS2) while downregulating matrix metallopeptidase 12 (MMP12), suggesting potential as a moisturizer and anti-aging agent.
population_specificity: Human skin fibroblasts

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Cordyceps sinensis extract and a probiotic on the productive performance of broilers.
results_summary: The study found that treatments combining Cordyceps sinensis extract and a probiotic (T6 and T7) significantly improved average body weight and feed conversion efficiency compared to other treatments. Cordyceps alone at 600 mg/kg feed (T3) also showed significant superiority in weight gain over some probiotic-only treatments.
population_specificity: One-day-old unsexed broiler chicks (Ross 308 strain).
effective_dosage: 300 mg/kg feed and 600 mg/kg feed of Cordyceps sinensis extract, alone or combined with a probiotic (3 g/kg feed or 6 g/kg feed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-tumor effects of wild Cordyceps polysaccharides (WCP) on H22 liver cancer and uncover the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: WCP inhibited H22 tumor proliferation by improving immune function and promoting tumor cell apoptosis, likely through the IL-10/STAT3/Bcl2 and Cyto-c/Caspase8/3 signaling pathways, with minimal side effects compared to 5-FU.
population_specificity: H22 tumor-bearing BALB/c mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the anticancer effect of Cordyceps militaris extract (CME) on breast cancer cells using hyaluronic acid-decorated lipid polymer hybrid nanoparticles (LPNPs) and evaluate the applicability of synthesized poly(glycerol adipate) polymers for LPNP preparation.
results_summary: The study found that HYA-decorated PGA-based LPNPs significantly improved the anticancer effect of CME against MDA-MB-231 and MCF-7 breast cancer cells by enhancing cellular uptake via CD44 receptor-mediated endocytosis. The LPNPs demonstrated promising potential for targeted herbal extract delivery in cancer treatment.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cells (MDA-MB-231 and MCF-7) in vitro.
effective_dosage: CME contained 9.89% cordycepin by weight (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the significance and molecular mechanisms of exogenous melatonin (MT) in alleviating strain degeneration in Cordyceps militaris during artificial cultivation.
results_summary: The study found that 60 μmol L-1 MT treatment reduced colony angulation and aerial hypha, lowered ROS and MDA levels, increased endogenous MT, and up-regulated antioxidant enzyme-related genes and genes involved in cordycepin, adenosine, and active compound biosynthesis.
population_specificity: Third-generation strain (W5-3) of Cordyceps militaris

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the nephroprotective effects of fermented Cordyceps sinensis on diabetic kidney disease (DKD) and identify its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Fermented Cordyceps sinensis significantly attenuated high glucose-induced cytotoxicity and apoptosis while promoting proliferation in renal proximal tubular cells, likely by targeting Caspase-3, Bax, VEGFA, and PTEN, and modulating AKT and ERK signaling pathways.
population_specificity: In vitro study using HK-2 cells (human renal proximal tubular cells) under high glucose conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of the recombinant CJPRB protein from Cordyceps javanica on the immune response and protective enzyme activity in Hyphantria cunea.
results_summary: The study found that CJPRB protein administration via infection, feeding, and injection induced changes in protective enzymes (SOD, POD, CAT, PPO) and immune defense-related genes in H. cunea, with injection eliciting the most rapid and intense immune response.
population_specificity: Hyphantria cunea (a globally distributed quarantine plant pest)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the molecular mechanism by which naphthalene acetic acid (NAA) enhances cordycepin yield in Cordyceps militaris and to elucidate the regulatory network of cordycepin synthesis.
results_summary: The study found that NAA treatment inhibited Cordyceps militaris growth but significantly increased cordycepin content. Transcriptome and metabolomics analysis revealed key metabolic pathways (purine metabolism, TCA cycle, etc.) and ABC transporter involvement in cordycepin synthesis, doubling its yield.
population_specificity: Cordyceps militaris (fungal culture)
effective_dosage: Different concentrations of NAA (specific amounts not detailed)

study_goal: To investigate whether Cordyceps sinensis protects against acute lung injury (ALI) induced by acute kidney injury (AKI) via the autophagy-related AMPK/mTOR signaling pathway.
results_summary: Cordyceps sinensis reduced lung injury markers, inflammatory cytokines, and oxidative stress biomarkers while modulating autophagy-related proteins (LC3-II/LC3-I, ULK1, P62, AMPK, mTOR), suggesting a protective effect against AKI-induced ALI.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with induced renal ischemia-reperfusion injury (IRI).
study_duration: Administered during reperfusion periods (12, 24, 48, and 72 h).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the therapeutic potential of Cordyceps proteins (CP) for lupus nephritis (LN) and uncover its underlying molecular mechanism.
results_summary: CP reduced proteinuria and renal inflammation in LN mice, outperformed artificial Cordyceps (BC) in regulating proteinuria and IL-4 levels, and modulated the STAT3/mTOR/NF-кB pathway, showing stronger anti-inflammatory effects than prednisolone acetate (PA).
population_specificity: MRL/lpr mice (a model for lupus nephritis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether nanoencapsulated cordyceps extract (CMP) could enhance neuronal maturation and function while alleviating neuronal pathology in human neural cells.
results_summary: CMP improved cellular uptake efficiency, inhibited neuroblastoma cell proliferation, increased mature neuronal markers and dopaminergic gene expression, and reduced Alzheimer-related gene expression and amyloid precursor protein secretion. It also upregulated autophagy activity.
population_specificity: Human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells (in vitro model).
study_duration: Treatment effects were observed within 6 hours, but total study duration is not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cordyceps militaris polysaccharides (CMP) could mitigate obesity-related metabolic disorders and gut dysbiosis in mice.
results_summary: CMP significantly reduced obesity, hyperlipidemia, insulin resistance, and systemic inflammation in high-fat diet-induced obese mice. It also restored gut microbiota diversity and increased beneficial SCFA-producing bacteria while reducing obesity-linked bacterial strains.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether artificially cultivated Cordyceps cicadae mycelia (CCM) could protect against cyclosporine A (CsA)-induced acute nephrotoxicity in rats and human renal cells.
results_summary: CCM significantly reduced CsA-induced kidney damage by lowering blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and endoplasmic reticulum stress markers, improving renal tubule vacuolization, and restoring magnesium ion channel protein expression. The protective effects were observed at both 40 mg/kg and 400 mg/kg doses.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats and human renal proximal tubular epithelial cell line HK-2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to collect and analyze data on the effects of Cordyceps spp. or cordycepin on bone function, osteogenesis, and related processes.
results_summary: The review found that Cordyceps spp. or cordycepin interacts via adenosine receptors, AMPK, and ATP signaling pathways, potentially aiding bone and dental pulp regeneration. It suggests Cordyceps could expand treatment options for bone diseases and injuries.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing data).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cordyceps guangdongensis lipid-lowering compound formula (CGLC) could regulate fat accumulation, gut microbiota, short-chain fatty acids, and lipid metabolism genes in high-fat diet mice.
results_summary: CGLC reduced body weight, fat accumulation, and liver lipid levels in mice, improved glucose tolerance and blood lipids, balanced gut microbiota, increased SCFA production, and regulated lipid metabolism genes.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether oral supplementation of fermented Cordyceps cicadae mycelium could mitigate dry eye conditions and related discomforts in humans.
results_summary: The study found that Cordyceps cicadae mycelium significantly increased tear film breakup time (TBUT) and decreased tear osmolarity and electrolytes (Na+ and Cl ions), suggesting improved tear quality, though tear volume did not significantly increase.
population_specificity: 70 healthy individuals
effective_dosage: 1,050 mg daily (containing 0.3 mg adenosine and 1.5 mg HEA per gram)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether D-Serine could reverse reduced Arc protein expression and dendritic spine deficits in SR-deficient mice, and its potential relevance to disorders like schizophrenia.
results_summary: D-Serine administration reversed reduced Arc protein expression in SR-deficient mice and partially rescued hippocampal spine deficits, highlighting its role in regulating Arc expression and spine plasticity.
population_specificity: SR-deficient (SR-/-) mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether endogenous glycine or D-serine activates the co-agonist site on presynaptic NMDA receptors in the entorhinal cortex and their role in glutamate release.
results_summary: The study found that D-serine, not glycine, is the endogenous agonist for presynaptic NMDA receptors, as its depletion significantly reduced glutamate release. Astroglial cells were identified as the source of D-serine, and their dysfunction mimicked the effects of D-serine depletion.
population_specificity: Rat entorhinal cortex neurons in vitro

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review genetic and neurobiological evidence linking NMDAR hypofunction to schizophrenia and explore potential NMDA receptor-augmenting treatments, including D-Serine.
results_summary: The abstract highlights NMDAR hypofunction as a potential cause of schizophrenia and suggests that augmenting NMDA receptor function could address synaptic deficits and cognitive impairments, though specific D-Serine results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with schizophrenia (focus on cognitive and negative symptoms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether positive modulation of the glycine site on the NMDA receptor, using D-serine, could attenuate negative symptoms of schizophrenia in an animal model.
results_summary: D-Serine significantly reversed the increased immobility induced by MK-801 in rats, suggesting potential efficacy against negative symptoms of schizophrenia. The effect was specific to MK-801-treated rats, with no impact on vehicle-treated rats.
population_specificity: Rats treated with MK-801 to model negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether D-Serine levels in the hippocampus are linked to spatial learning and memory impairment in diabetic rats and if insulin treatment could mitigate these effects.
results_summary: The study found elevated D-Serine, glutamate, and serine racemase levels in diabetic rats, correlating with impaired learning and memory. Insulin treatment normalized these levels and improved cognitive function.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats induced by streptozotocin (STZ).
study_duration: Insulin treatment began 3 days post-STZ injection (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prebiotic compounds (FOS and GOS) affect brain BDNF and NMDARs, including D-Serine levels, and explore potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: GOS intake increased hippocampal NR2A subunits and frontal cortex NR1 and D-Serine levels, suggesting enhanced NMDAR signaling. Plasma from GOS-treated rats increased BDNF release from neuroblastoma cells, potentially mediated by gut hormones like PYY.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether peripheral NMDA receptor-related glutamatergic amino acid levels, particularly D-Serine, were altered in patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia compared to controls and whether clozapine treatment affected these levels.
results_summary: The study found that plasma D-Serine levels and the D-/L-Serine ratio were significantly lower in treatment-resistant schizophrenia patients before clozapine treatment compared to controls. Clozapine treatment increased the D-/L-Serine ratio and glycine/L-Serine ratio, suggesting these ratios could be markers of therapeutic efficacy.
population_specificity: 22 patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia and 22 age- and gender-matched healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether baseline plasma concentrations of D-serine and L-serine could predict antidepressant response to (R,S)-ketamine in patients with treatment-resistant depression.
results_summary: Baseline D-serine plasma concentrations were significantly lower in ketamine responders than non-responders, and D-serine levels explained 60% of the variance in antidepressant response. L-serine concentrations were also significantly lower in responders.
population_specificity: 21 patients with treatment-resistant depression (8 responders, 13 non-responders).
effective_dosage: Not specified (plasma concentrations measured, not administered).
study_duration: Single infusion, measurements taken at baseline and 230 minutes post-infusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of exogenous D-serine administration on adult neurogenesis in the mouse dentate gyrus.
results_summary: D-serine treatment increased cell proliferation in vivo and in vitro, enhanced the density of neural stem cells and transit amplifying progenitors, and improved the survival of newborn neurons. These results suggest D-serine positively impacts multiple steps of adult neurogenesis.
population_specificity: Adult mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, safety, tolerability, and efficacy of combining D-serine with cognitive retraining (CRT) for treating cognitive deficits in schizophrenia.
results_summary: D-serine and CRT were well tolerated but did not significantly improve the Global Cognitive Index. CRT alone showed significant improvement in Verbal Working Memory and a trend in Attention/Vigilance, with differential site effects observed.
population_specificity: 104 schizophrenia patients (22 from the US, 82 from India).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of subchronic treatment with D-Serine on spatial discrimination learning, open-field activity, and social interaction in APPswe/PS1 mutant mice with amyloid pathology.
results_summary: D-Serine (50mg/kg, i.p.) improved reversal learning in mutant mice but had weaker effects on open-field hyperactivity and social interaction. The results suggest a favorable action of D-Serine on reversal learning in mice with amyloid pathology.
population_specificity: APPswe/PS1 mutant mice with Aβ plaques in the brain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether antidepressants, particularly SSRIs like fluoxetine and citalopram, could reduce the release of D-Serine from activated microglia and improve cortical neuronal survival after ischemic injury.
results_summary: The study found that fluoxetine and citalopram decreased the release of D-Serine from LPS-activated microglia, which contributed to increased survival of oxygen-glucose deprived cortical neurons in co-culture. Microglial release of D-Serine was identified as a key factor mediating neuronal survival.
population_specificity: Primary microglia and cortical neurons in vitro (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neonatal disruption of D-serine synthesis by SRR inhibition could induce schizophrenia-like behavioral abnormalities later in life and whether D-serine could prevent or mitigate these effects.
results_summary: Neonatal SRR inhibition reduced D-serine levels and caused schizophrenia-relevant behavioral abnormalities in juvenile and adult mice. D-serine administration improved PPI deficits in adults and prevented the onset of such deficits when administered chronically.
population_specificity: Neonatal mice (7-9 days old), evaluated at juvenile (5-6 weeks) and adult (10-12 weeks) stages.
effective_dosage: Met-Phen (3 mg/kg/day), D-serine (single dose and chronic 900 mg/kg/day from P35 to P70).
study_duration: Chronic D-serine administration lasted from postnatal day 35 to 70.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether D-serine could serve as a therapeutic breakthrough for schizophrenia, particularly for negative and cognitive symptoms, by targeting glutamatergic dysfunction.
results_summary: The study suggests that D-serine may improve symptoms of schizophrenia, especially where conventional treatments fail, based on animal data, genetic studies, and clinical trials. Evidence supports further research into increasing brain D-serine levels or mimicking its action on NMDA receptors.
population_specificity: Individuals with schizophrenia, particularly those with negative and cognitive symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether D-Serine could improve polyI:C-induced emotional, cognitive, and sensorimotor gating impairments in mice by potentiating NMDA receptor activity.
results_summary: D-Serine dose-dependently improved emotional and cognitive impairments in polyI:C-treated mice but had no effect on sensorimotor gating deficits. Its effects were blocked by the NMDA-receptor antagonist MK-801, suggesting NMDA receptor involvement.
population_specificity: Neonatal ICR mice treated with polyI:C from postnatal day 2 to 6, assessed in adulthood (10 weeks).
study_duration: 5 days (polyI:C treatment), D-Serine intervention duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between plasma D-serine levels and schizophrenia, focusing on its potential role in NMDA receptor hypofunction and symptom severity.
results_summary: The study found significantly lower plasma D-serine levels and D-serine-to-total-serine ratios in individuals with schizophrenia compared to controls. D-serine levels were negatively correlated with the severity of negative symptoms and decreased with aging in healthy controls.
population_specificity: 84 Brazilian individuals with schizophrenia and 75 gender- and age-matched controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of D-amino acid oxidase (DAAO) in the pharmacokinetics of oral D-serine and its potential therapeutic implications for schizophrenia.
results_summary: The study found that D-serine levels were rapidly diminished in wild-type mice but sustained in mice lacking DAAO. Coadministration with a DAAO inhibitor (CBIO) temporarily enhanced plasma D-serine levels, suggesting DAAO plays a predominant role in D-serine clearance.
population_specificity: Wild-type and transgenic mice lacking DAAO.
interactions: CBIO (a DAAO inhibitor) was noted to interact with D-serine metabolism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding D-Serine to antipsychotics could improve negative symptoms and cognition in patients with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in improvement of negative symptoms or cognition between D-Serine and placebo groups, despite both groups showing some improvement. D-Serine was well tolerated.
population_specificity: Inpatients or outpatients with DSM-IV schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder, stabilized on antipsychotics but with persistent negative symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the dose-dependent effects of D-serine on extinction training and drug-primed reinstatement in cocaine-conditioned rats.
results_summary: D-serine did not affect cocaine-induced locomotor sensitization or CPP acquisition but significantly reduced drug-seeking behavior when combined with extinction training, with effects lasting over four weeks post-treatment.
population_specificity: Cocaine-conditioned rats
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (follow-up lasted more than four weeks post-treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of D-Serine in diabetes mellitus (DM) pathology, specifically its regulation in the hippocampus during acute and chronic phases of DM.
results_summary: The study found that STZ-induced DM transiently increased hippocampal D-Serine levels at 1 week, which was restored by insulin treatment. L-glutamate levels were also altered, but these changes were not evident in chronic phases.
population_specificity: STZ-treated diabetic mice (animal model).
study_duration: Acute (3 days, 1 week) and chronic phases after DM induction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of NSAIDs against D-serine-induced oxidative stress in the rat brain in vitro.
results_summary: The study found that NSAIDs (mefenamic acid, acetaminophen, and naproxen sodium) significantly reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, lipid peroxidation, and protein oxidation caused by D-serine treatment.
population_specificity: Rat brain tissue in vitro

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neurotoxic effects of D-Serine on oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis in rat brain regions and assess the protective potential of mefenamic acid.
results_summary: D-Serine significantly increased oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis markers in the hippocampus, cortex, and cerebellum of rats. Mefenamic acid provided significant protection against these effects, reducing lipid peroxidation, protein oxidation, and levels of TNF-α, IL-1β, and Bax.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of the SR/d-serine pathway in neuronal apoptosis and its impact on survival, particularly in relation to NMDAR dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found that SR/d-serine pathway modulation plays a crucial role in neuronal apoptosis, with early-phase reduction in SR expression exacerbating death and late-phase SR increase contributing to NMDAR-mediated cell death. Forced SR expression combined with NMDA and d-serine treatment blocked neuronal death, while SR inhibition worsened it.
population_specificity: Cerebellar granule neurons (CGNs) undergoing apoptosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the dendritic pathology in pyramidal neurons caused by D-Serine deprivation required developmental absence or only adulthood loss of D-Serine.
results_summary: The study found that neuronally derived D-Serine in adulthood is required for optimal dendritic arborization and spine density in pyramidal neurons, with significant reductions observed in both SR-/- and nSR-/- mice, though to a lesser degree in the latter. The effects varied between apical and basal dendrites, highlighting the role of D-Serine in synaptic regulation.
population_specificity: SR knockout (SR-/-) mice and mice with forebrain glutamatergic neuron-specific SR knockout (nSR-/-).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether long-term dietary supplementation with L-NAC could restore D-serine-dependent NMDA-R activation and synaptic plasticity in aged rats.
results_summary: Chronic L-NAC treatment restored D-serine levels, NMDA-R activation, and long-term potentiation (LTP) in aged rats, reversing age-related synaptic plasticity deficits. Exogenous D-serine also reversed these deficits, indicating its critical role in NMDA-R function.
population_specificity: Aged rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the evolutionary selection and metabolic pathways of amino acid neurotransmitters, including D-Serine, and their implications in inherited metabolic diseases.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the metabolic precursors of D-Serine and its role as a neurotransmitter but does not provide specific findings on its effects or outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of metabolic diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic potential of D-Serine in neurological and psychiatric disorders, as well as its role in conditions linked to L-serine deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that D-Serine, a metabolic product of L-serine, has therapeutic potential in central nervous system injuries and a range of neurological and psychiatric disorders, though specific efficacy data were not detailed.
population_specificity: Humans with disorders related to L-serine deficiency, neurological conditions, or psychiatric disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of D-serine in the pre-symptomatic and progression phases of ALS, particularly its regulation by serine racemase (SR) and its effects in a mouse model of ALS.
results_summary: The study found that D-serine levels are elevated in ALS mice, and disrupting SR alters disease onset and progression. Paradoxically, D-serine administration reduced cord levels of D-serine and affected disease progression similarly to SR deletion, while also increasing levels of the Asc-1 transporter.
population_specificity: G93A Cu,Zn-superoxide dismutase (SOD1) mice, a standard model of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of l-serine supplementation in patients with GRIN2B-related neurodevelopmental disorder (NDD) due to loss-of-function variants.
results_summary: Both patients tolerated l-serine without adverse effects. One patient showed significant improvement in psychomotor development and cognitive functioning, while the other, more severely affected patient, showed no significant objective improvement, though caregivers reported subjective improvements in alertness and communication.
population_specificity: Two female patients (18 months and 4 years old) with GRIN2B-NDD and loss-of-function variants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of D-Serine as an adjunct to antipsychotic treatments in patients with schizophrenia.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that D-Serine, when added to antipsychotic treatments, showed significant improvement in symptom severity among schizophrenia patients, though specific efficacy details were not fully elaborated. Safety profiles, including discontinuation rates and adverse events, were assessed as secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with schizophrenia (4,937 participants across 40 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of D-serine in age-related hippocampal functional plasticity and memory deficits, and whether oxidative stress affects D-serine levels and NMDAR activation.
results_summary: The study found that D-serine supplementation rescues memory deficits and synaptic plasticity in aging, with deficits linked to decreased D-serine levels and SR expression. Aged LOU/C rats, a healthy aging model, showed no such deficits, suggesting oxidative stress may target the D-serine pathway.
population_specificity: Aging rats (senescent rats and LOU/C rats as a healthy aging model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether NMDAR stimulation via D-Serine could be beneficial in late-phase Parkinson's disease, based on its potential to alleviate parkinsonian symptoms and improve motor disturbances.
results_summary: The study suggests that D-Serine may alleviate antipsychotic-induced parkinsonian symptoms and improve motor disturbances associated with NMDAR hypofunction, supported by preliminary trial data and animal models. No excitotoxic damage was observed with chronic high-dose glycine supplementation, indicating potential safety.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease and related motor disturbances, including those with antipsychotic-induced parkinsonian symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify key genes associated with ketosis and residual feed intake (RFI) in high-yield dairy cows to explore potential biomarkers and therapeutic targets.
results_summary: The study identified three genes (ACACA, ELOVL6, XPO7) as regulators of ketosis induced by low feed intake and three additional genes (HRFI, STAT3, IFNAR1) as potential RFI biomarkers in dairy cows. These findings may provide a theoretical basis for targeted ketosis therapy.
population_specificity: High-yield dairy cows
