study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the accuracy of various diagnostic tests for identifying uterine infection in dairy cows and assess their practical utility in different scenarios.
results_summary: Laboratory bacterial culture was the most accurate test (sensitivity = 0.87, specificity = 0.71), while on-farm tools like Petrifilm, Tri-Plate, and PVD were less sensitive. Luminometry showed promise but requires further research for practical implementation.
population_specificity: Dairy cows between 29 and 43 days in milk from seven farms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the magnitude and epidemiological characteristics of calf morbidity and mortality in smallholder dairy farms in Northern Ethiopia.
results_summary: The study found high rates of calf morbidity (69.4% via survey, 75.5% via proportional piling) and mortality (63.9% via survey, 55.9% via proportional piling), with key risk factors including water source, barn hygiene, and colostrum provision. Leading causes were diarrhea, nutritional disorders, pneumonia, and navel ill, compounded by poor infrastructure and veterinary services.
population_specificity: Smallholder dairy farms in Northern Ethiopia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of gaseous ozone (50 ppm) in controlling planktonic and sessile Bacillus cereus and Bacillus subtilis isolates from the dairy sector, as well as its impact on biofilm inhibition and eradication.
results_summary: Gaseous ozone (50 ppm) effectively reduced planktonic cells of B. cereus and B. subtilis, with complete inactivation after 6 hours. It also showed varying effectiveness against biofilms, with B. subtilis being more sensitive than B. cereus, though biofilm eradication was incomplete.
population_specificity: Bacillus cereus and Bacillus subtilis isolates collected from the dairy sector.
study_duration: 10 minutes, 1 hour, and 6 hours for planktonic cells; 6 hours for biofilm evaluation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of replacing grass-clover silage (GCS) with re-ensiled press cake silage (PCS) in dairy cows' diets on feed intake, milk production, digestibility, and behavior.
results_summary: Replacing GCS with PCS did not significantly affect energy-corrected milk production or feed conversion but improved crude protein and phosphorus utilization. Milk composition remained similar except for lower urea content in the PCS50 group.
population_specificity: Six Holstein Friesian and nine Simmental cows (average 624 ± 68 kg body weight, 60 ± 20 days in milk).
effective_dosage: Three TMR diets with varying PCS/GCS proportions: 0% PCS + 50% GCS (CON), 25% PCS + 25% GCS (PCS25), and 50% PCS + 0% GCS (PCS50).
study_duration: Three experimental runs, each lasting 35 days (14-day adaptation, 21-day measurement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the decision-making process of animal health providers in managing mastitis in small-holder dairy farms in Kenya.
results_summary: Most AHPs diagnosed mastitis based on clinical symptoms without diagnostic testing, and antibiotic use varied by severity, with β-lactams and aminoglycosides commonly used. AHPs with larger client bases and those avoiding antibiotics for mild cases had better attitude scores.
population_specificity: Animal health providers (114) in small-holder dairy farms in Kiambu County, Kenya.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Polygain™ (PG) supplementation could reduce enteric methane emissions in Holstein Friesian weaned calves without adversely affecting their growth.
results_summary: PG supplementation significantly reduced methane emissions (26.66 ± 2.06 g/day vs. 35.28 ± 1.39 g/day in controls, p < 0.001) and altered the CO2/O2 ratio, with no adverse effects on calf growth.
population_specificity: 24 female Holstein Friesian weaned calves (4-5 months old) grazing on annual pasture.
effective_dosage: 10 g PG per calf per day, delivered via supplementary pellets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare reproductive performance and economic impacts of dairy heifers undergoing two different synchronization programs (m5dC vs. 7dC) for fixed-time artificial insemination.
results_summary: The modified 5-day Cosynch program (m5dC) significantly improved conception rates (62.0% vs. 45.4%) and 6-week pregnancy rates (87.6% vs. 74.4%) compared to the 7-day Cosynch program (7dC), with a net economic return of NZ$72.29 per heifer. No difference in final pregnancy rate was detected.
population_specificity: Maiden dairy heifers (n=565) from four New Zealand dairy farms.
effective_dosage: m5dC: 500 μg cloprostenol (Days -10, -3, -2), 100 μg GnRH (Days -8, 0); 7dC: 100 μg GnRH (Day -10), 500 μg cloprostenol (Day -3), 100 μg GnRH (Day -1). CIDR inserts used for 5 or 7 days.
study_duration: Up to 10 weeks of mating following synchronization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze antimicrobial resistance and virulence-associated genes in bacterial pathogens (Pasteurella multocida and Mannheimia haemolytica) causing bovine respiratory disease in calves.
results_summary: The study found high resistance to commonly used antibiotics (e.g., tetracyclines, penicillin) in both bacterial species, with P. multocida showing higher resistance to chlortetracycline and oxytetracycline, while M. haemolytica exhibited resistance to penicillin and tilmicosin. Fluoroquinolones were the most effective, with high susceptibility rates in both species. All strains carried at least one virulence gene.
population_specificity: Calves affected by bovine respiratory disease in Poland.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of sub-inhibitory concentrations of cadmium chloride and benzalkonium chloride on antibiotic resistance and virulence factor expression in Staphylococcus isolates from food.
results_summary: The study found that sub-inhibitory concentrations of benzalkonium chloride and cadmium chloride increased antibiotic resistance, biofilm production, and virulence gene expression in Staphylococcus strains, suggesting potential risks of using low disinfectant concentrations in the food industry.
population_specificity: Staphylococcus isolates (S. epidermidis, S. heamolyticus, S. saprophyticus, and S. aureus) from food.
effective_dosage: Sub-inhibitory concentrations (SICs) of cadmium chloride and benzalkonium chloride (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore alternative therapeutic strategies for the prevention and treatment of bovine mastitis in dairy cattle, focusing on replacing conventional antibiotic therapy.
results_summary: The study reviewed various alternative treatments for bovine mastitis, including nanoparticle therapy, bacteriophage therapy, vaccination, phytotherapy, animal proteins, probiotics, and bacteriocins, highlighting potential synergistic benefits from combining these approaches.
population_specificity: Dairy cattle affected by bovine mastitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a single administration of hCG on day 2 of the estrus cycle on circulating progesterone concentrations and pregnancy per artificial insemination in high-producing lactating dairy cows.
results_summary: Treatment with hCG increased pregnancy per artificial insemination (45.2% vs. control 38.8%), particularly in cows in third or greater lactation (42.1% vs. control 27.3%). hCG also elevated progesterone concentrations on days 7 and 14 compared to controls.
population_specificity: High-producing lactating Holstein-Friesian dairy cows in confinement systems (796 cows from 15 farms).
study_duration: Single dose administered on day 2 of the estrus cycle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of an anti-heat stress lick block supplement on milk production, milk quality, feed intake, rectal temperature, respiratory rate, and rumen fermentation in heat-stressed dairy cows.
results_summary: The lick block supplementation improved milk yield and reduced respiratory rate, while also positively affecting rumen pH and fermentation parameters, though it did not significantly alter milk composition or overall rectal temperature.
population_specificity: Twenty-four healthy Holstein lactating dairy cows, divided by milk yield, parity (2-3), and lactation days (114 ± 8 d).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two hoof trimming methods (LIT and BIGM) on the occurrence of new hoof lesions and lameness risk in dairy cows during the next lactation.
results_summary: The study found no overall difference between LIT and BIGM methods in preventing hoof lesions or lameness, but first-lactation cows and those with lower initial lameness scores benefited more from BIGM, showing reduced lesion risk and delayed lameness onset.
population_specificity: Dairy cows from three sand-bedded freestall herds in Wisconsin and Minnesota, without hoof horn lesions at dry-off.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (hoof trimming methods compared, not a dosage-based intervention).
study_duration: Follow-up until next hoof trimming (median ~113 DIM) or up to 165 DIM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a self-developed herbal formula as a dietary intervention to mitigate heat stress in dairy cows and improve their productivity, health, and welfare.
results_summary: The herbal formula improved feed intake, milk yield and quality, rumination frequency, antioxidant activity, immune response, and rumen microbiome composition in dairy cows under heat stress. It also enhanced metabolic pathways related to energy utilization and fermentation efficiency.
population_specificity: 198 lactating dairy cows divided into Control and Herbs groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of different nitrogen forms on microalgae and bacteria in treating dairy farm wastewater, focusing on material/gene transfer and nitrogen metabolic pathways.
results_summary: High ammonia nitrogen concentrations reduced microalgae dry weight and chlorophyll a production, while appropriate nitrogen levels enhanced phosphorus and ammonia nitrogen removal. Nitrate nitrogen improved electron transfer in photosynthesis, and organic nitrogen aided siderophore synthesis.
population_specificity: Dairy farm wastewater treated with Chlorella vulgaris microalgae.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of replacing soybean meal (SBM) with defatted black soldier fly larvae meal (DBSFLM) on feed intake, milk production, and digestibility in lactating dairy cows.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in milk yield or composition between cows fed SBM, DBSFLM, or a 50:50 mix. However, dry matter and organic matter intake were higher for SBM-fed cows, while NDF and ADF digestibility were lower compared to DBSFLM-fed cows.
population_specificity: Twelve lactating Holstein-Friesian cows.
effective_dosage: Three protein treatments: SBM (control), 50:50 SBM:DBSFLM, and DBSFLM.
study_duration: 18 days per period in a replicated 3×3 Latin square design.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inflammatory response mechanisms in dairy cows infected with F.necrophorum, focusing on tissue changes and signaling pathways.
results_summary: F.necrophorum infection increased epidermal thickness, inflammatory cell infiltration, and pro-inflammatory cytokine expression in cattle skin explants and fibroblasts. Treatment with TNFR1 inhibitor CAY10500 reduced inflammation by inhibiting the TNF-α/TNFR1/NF-κB pathway.
population_specificity: Dairy cows with foot rot.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and operational cost of different acaricidal treatments (varying droplet size, pressure, and spray pattern) for controlling Rhipicephalus microplus in dairy cows.
results_summary: The study found no statistical differences in tick counts between treated groups, but higher efficacy was observed with larger droplets (medium and ultra coarse) and higher pressure (100 psi). The effective operational cost ranged between 0.42 and 0.46 USD per animal.
population_specificity: Dairy cows (three groups of 10 animals per experiment).
effective_dosage: Acaricide treatment (organophosphate and pyrethroid-based) applied once on day 0.
study_duration: Tick counts were performed up to 21 days post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review methods for valorizing dairy waste into useful products and identify the best approach for environmental sustainability.
results_summary: The study found that dairy waste can be converted into valuable products like biogas, biofertilizers, biopolymers, and biosurfactants through thermochemical, biological, and integrated pathways, with potential for environmental and economic benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine and associate dairy farmers' knowledge and attitude with their reproductive hormone use behavior in dairy cows.
results_summary: The study found that higher knowledge scores and stronger attitudes toward hormone benefits were positively associated with hormone use behavior, while attitudes favoring non-hormonal fertility management were linked to lower actual hormone use. No significant association was found between knowledge and attitude factors.
population_specificity: Dairy farmers (188 respondents) managing cow fertility.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence of hoof disorders in intensive dairy farms in Korea and their association with farm conditions.
results_summary: The study found that 31.5% of cattle had hoof disorders, with hoof overgrowth being the most common. Poor farm conditions, such as aggressive hoof treatment and sharp floor elevation transitions, were linked to higher prevalence of specific disorders like bovine digital dermatitis and laminitis/corium damage.
population_specificity: 877 cattle from 15 intensive dairy farms in Korea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a tannin-based feed additive (ByPro®) on reproductive efficiency in lactating cows, specifically measuring services per conception and days open.
results_summary: The tannin feed additive significantly improved artificial insemination efficiency, reducing services per conception by 9% and days open by 6.3% during the treatment period. Comparable effects persisted post-treatment, suggesting potential carryover benefits from rumen microbiota changes.
population_specificity: Lactating cows on a commercial dairy farm (two units of ~3000 cows each).
effective_dosage: 0.3% of total estimated dry matter intake per cow.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of dairy farming extension programs on the welfare of Maasai livestock keepers, focusing on milk production and income improvements.
results_summary: Participation in dairy farming extension programs increased milk production by 5.751 liters per day and monthly income by 11,670 TSHS, with participants earning 55,010 TSHS more than non-participants. The study highlighted the role of demographic factors, social capital, and education in program participation and welfare outcomes.
population_specificity: Maasai livestock keepers in Engaruka, Lepurko, and Selela wards, Monduli District, Arusha, Tanzania (431 participants: 221 treated, 210 control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effectiveness of a subsurface flow constructed wetland (CW) system combined with an aerated facultative lagoon for treating dairy industry wastewater.
results_summary: The integrated system (Lagoon + CW) achieved high pollutant removal rates (>98% for COD, BOD5, TSS, and surfactants) for the first seven years, but clogging and surface flow reduced efficiency afterward, suggesting a maximum operational period before substrate replacement is needed.
population_specificity: Dairy industry wastewater treatment systems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to rank dry off interventions for preventing new intramammary infections (IMI) and curing existing IMI in dairy cows during the dry period.
results_summary: Selective and blanket dry cow therapy, especially when combined with internal teat sealants, improved cure risk for existing IMI and maintained low incidence risk for new IMI, with no significant differences between antimicrobial-based interventions. Selective dry cow therapy with internal teat sealant was identified as a suitable option to reduce antimicrobial use while maintaining efficacy.
population_specificity: Dry dairy cows

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an advanced oxidation process (electro-Fenton) using a MIL-88 A(Fe)/C composite to reduce organic pollutants in dairy wastewater.
results_summary: The study found that under optimized conditions (pH 7.0, 102.6 min contact time, 0.5 g/L catalyst, 0.026 M oxidizer), the electro-Fenton process achieved 86.6% (statistical) and 89% (experimental) COD removal efficiency in dairy wastewater. The results were competitive with prior research on dairy industry wastewater treatment.
population_specificity: Wastewater from the Isfahan Pegah Dairy factory.
effective_dosage: 0.5 g/L MIL-88 A(Fe)/C catalyst, 0.026 M Na2S2O8 oxidizer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily intake of fortified yogurt with probiotics, vitamin E, and vitamin D could improve psychological status and sleep quality in women with PCOS.
results_summary: The study found that the fortified yogurt significantly improved depression status in women with PCOS but did not show a statistically beneficial impact on sleep quality.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
effective_dosage: 106 colony-forming units/g of probiotics (Bifidobacterium animalis Bb-12 and Lactobacillus acidophilus La-5), 50 IU of vitamin E, and 1,000 IU of vitamin D daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of integrating bio-electrochemical treatment with anaerobic digestion of dairy manure to improve biogas production, reduce hydrogen sulfide release, and remediate nutrients in digestate.
results_summary: The integrated system (CSTR-BEC) significantly outperformed the control, increasing methane content by 42.5%, achieving 89% removal of gaseous H2S, and removing 49.5-63.7% of soluble and total phosphorus. The net energy gain remained comparable to the control despite higher power consumption.
population_specificity: Liquid dairy manure (industrial/agricultural context)
effective_dosage: Applied voltages of 0.5-0.8 V in the BEC unit

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of hCG administered on day 5 or day 7 after estrus on luteal structures and pregnancy rates in estrus-induced dairy goats during the non-breeding season.
results_summary: hCG treatment did not improve pregnancy rates but transiently enhanced luteal function and vascularization, with hCG-7 showing greater total luteal area and higher progesterone concentrations compared to controls.
population_specificity: Alpine dairy goats during the non-breeding season.
effective_dosage: 300 IU hCG administered once on day 5 (hCG-5) or day 7 (hCG-7) after estrus.
study_duration: Intervention lasted until day 21, with pregnancy diagnosis on day 60.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of allocating concentrate feed inside versus outside the milking robot on dairy cow behavior, productivity, and welfare.
results_summary: The study found no effect of concentrate allocation on milking frequency, refused milkings, or lying time. Cows with more concentrate outside the robot visited the out-of-parlour feeder more often, while those with more inside the robot left more concentrate unconsumed, suggesting potential energy target shortfalls.
population_specificity: 48 mid-late lactation dairy cows
effective_dosage: 80% of concentrate ration inside the milking robot (robot high) or 80% via an out-of-parlour feeder (robot low)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of niacin supplementation (rumen-unprotected or rumen-protected) on lactational performance in dairy cows during transition or lactation periods.
results_summary: Niacin supplementation during the lactation period (but not the transition period) improved milk production, with rumen-unprotected niacin (9.1 g/d) and rumen-protected niacin (4.7 g/d) increasing milk yield by 0.83 kg/d and 0.96 kg/d, respectively. Feed efficiency was not improved.
population_specificity: Dairy cows during transition or lactation periods
effective_dosage: 9.1 g/d rumen-unprotected niacin or 4.7 g/d rumen-protected niacin

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a novel bacterial 6-phytase (PhyG) on nutrient digestibility and excretion in lactating dairy cows to reduce environmental impacts.
results_summary: PhyG supplementation improved apparent total-tract digestibility of phytate-P, P, CP, and NDF, reduced fecal excretion of these nutrients, and tended to increase milk protein yield without affecting dry matter intake, body weight, or milk yield.
population_specificity: Forty-eight lactating Holstein-Friesian cows averaging 44.1 kg milk/day and 124 days in milk at the start.
effective_dosage: 2,000 or 5,000 phytase units/kg DM of PhyG.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate veterinarians' communication skills during herd health and production management (HHPM) visits on Flemish dairy farms to identify areas for improvement.
results_summary: The study found that certain communication processes like 'History taking' and 'Presenting information' were prevalent, while others like 'Agenda setting' and 'Needs determination' were often lacking. Veterinarians with less experience or more HHPM visits performed better in specific communication aspects, but efforts to incorporate 'Partnership' and 'Empathy' were inconsistent.
population_specificity: Dairy veterinarians and dairy farmers in Flanders, Belgium.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the performance of three dairy feed evaluation systems (NRC, NASEM, CNCPS) in predicting intestinal digestible flows of essential amino acids (DigFlowEAA) and their net portal appearance (NPA) in dairy cows.
results_summary: The study found that predictions of NPA for branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) and Thr were consistently overpredicted across all three systems, while other EAA showed variable biases. The results suggest oxidation of certain amino acids by the portal-drained viscera (PDV) and potential synthesis of Arg, with duodenal sampling appearing more representative of true EAA supply than omasal sampling.
population_specificity: Dairy cows (83 treatment means from 25 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of milk fortification with advanced chelated trace minerals on growth performance and health in dairy calves.
results_summary: Calves receiving chelated trace minerals showed improved body weight, lower fecal consistency index, reduced medical treatments, and better blood metabolite profiles compared to control and inorganic mineral groups. Inorganic sources showed no benefits.
population_specificity: Forty-two Holstein dairy calves (21 male and 21 female).
effective_dosage: Not specified (daily milk fortification from day 3 until weaning at 70 days).
study_duration: 67 days (from day 3 to weaning at 70 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare fertility traits, health indicators, and management routines between Swiss dairy farms with short vs. long productive lifespans to determine if longer lifespans negatively impact cow health.
results_summary: Farms with longer productive lifespans showed better fertility performance and no significant health trade-offs, except for a slight increase in somatic cell scores with age. Limb and udder health remained comparable between the two groups.
population_specificity: Swiss dairy farms (n = 142 herdbook data, n = 67 questionnaire data, n = 64 veterinary treatment data, n = 30 farm visits).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of indigenous and cultivated microalgae in nutrient removal and biomass production in dairy wastewater, focusing on microbial function changes.
results_summary: The study found higher phosphorus removal and biomass production in sterile dairy wastewater, while nitrogen removal was higher in non-sterile wastewater. Indigenous strains grew more consistently in high-concentration wastewater, and phycosphere bacteria communities were closely associated with nutrient and pigment content.
population_specificity: Dairy wastewater (not human or animal subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate greenhouse gas emissions (GHGei) from New York dairy farms, identify key contributors to emissions, and determine performance indicators influencing GHGei.
results_summary: The study found that methane was the largest contributor (60%) to total GHG emissions, primarily from enteric fermentation (45%). Manure management and feed production were significant sources, with variation in GHGei linked to farm practices like manure systems and heifer-to-cow ratios.
population_specificity: 36 medium to large commercial dairy farms in New York (>300 mature cows).
study_duration: Assessments were conducted for the year 2022.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess veterinary service delivery, preferences, and satisfaction among dairy farms in central Ethiopia.
results_summary: The study found that private veterinary services were dominant and preferred for most treatments, though dissatisfaction with high costs and insufficient medicine was reported. Farmers were highly satisfied with veterinary professionals' skills and animal recovery rates.
population_specificity: 381 dairy farms in central Ethiopia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of leptin and its receptor OB-Rb in regulating milk fat synthesis in dairy cow mammary tissues and cultured mammary epithelial cells.
results_summary: The study found that leptin and OB-Rb expression were higher in lactating cows, and leptin treatment increased OB-Rb expression and triacylglycerol content in mammary epithelial cells. It also identified activation of the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway and upregulation of milk fat synthesis-related genes.
population_specificity: Dairy cow mammary tissues and cultured mammary epithelial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the seroprevalence and spatial distribution of liver fluke infection in dairy herds in the West Coast and Canterbury regions of New Zealand using bulk milk ELISA.
results_summary: The study found a high seroprevalence of liver fluke infection in West Coast dairy herds, particularly in coastal areas, with 63% and 50% of herds showing production-limiting infections in March and October, respectively. No production-limiting infections were detected in Canterbury herds, and coastal herds had significantly higher odds of infection compared to inland herds.
population_specificity: Dairy herds in the West Coast and Canterbury regions of New Zealand.
study_duration: Sampled twice in March 2017 (a week apart) and once in October 2017.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze mastitis prevalence, pathogens, treatments, and risk factors in a commercial dairy farm setting.
results_summary: Mastitis occurrence was highest in summer, first lactation, and late lactation stages, with coagulase-negative staphylococci being the leading pathogen. Antibiotics (cephalosporins and aminoglycosides) were used in 75% of cases, with an average treatment duration of 3.48 days.
population_specificity: 1537 cows from a commercial dairy farm in Germany.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of supplementing different feed additives (yeast, essential oils, and peptides) to diets containing K2CO3 on feed intake, nutrient digestion, and milk production in dairy cows.
results_summary: Supplementing with yeast increased feed intake, while essential oils improved energy-corrected milk yield. Milk protein production was higher in essential oil and peptide treatments compared to the control.
population_specificity: Eight peak lactation high-yielding Holstein cows.
effective_dosage: K2CO3 (6% of dietary dry matter, 10% K), yeast (0.06% of DDM), essential oils (0.02% of DDM), peptides (0.16% of DDM).
study_duration: 21 days per period (14 days adaptation, 7 days sampling).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active ingredients, potential targets, and mechanisms of action of peppermint in treating bovine mastitis.
results_summary: The study identified 28 cross targets between peppermint and bovine mastitis, with apigenin, luteolin, and ursolic acid as key components. Molecular docking showed strong binding activity between peppermint constituents and core targets, suggesting potential therapeutic efficacy.
population_specificity: Bovine mastitis (dairy cows)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nanofabricated GnRH and PGF2α in enhancing reproductive performance in heat-stressed dairy cows using the Ovsynch protocol.
results_summary: The ¼ OVS protocol (reduced dosage) achieved significantly better follicular response and higher pregnancy rates (65%) compared to the control (40%). Nanofabrication allowed dose reduction without impairing ovarian response or fertility.
population_specificity: Cyclic purebred Friesian cows not detected in standing heat for over 90 days postpartum.
effective_dosage: 2.5 µg GnRH-CNPs (days 0, 9) and 125 µg PGF2α-CNPs (day 7) for ¼ OVS group; 5 µg GnRH-CNPs (days 0, 9) and 250 µg PGF2α-CNPs (day 7) for ½ OVS group.
study_duration: 9-day protocol with follow-up until day 30 post-AI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of rumen-protected glutathione (RPGSH) supplementation on lactation, nutrient metabolism, oxidative stress, inflammation, and health in transition dairy cows.
results_summary: Supplementation with 2 g/d RPGSH reduced somatic cell count and postpartum disease incidence, improved fat-corrected milk and feed efficiency, and enhanced antioxidant and anti-inflammatory markers without affecting milk yield or composition. Higher glucose and lower β-hydroxybutyrate levels were also observed in the RPGSH group.
population_specificity: Forty Holstein dairy cows in transition (21 days prepartum to 21 days postpartum).
effective_dosage: 0 g/d (control), 1.5 g/d (T1), 2 g/d (T2), 3 g/d (T3) of RPGSH.
study_duration: Approximately 42 days (21 days prepartum to 21 days postpartum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of increasing levels of a polyherbal phytogenic additive (PPA) on growth performance, health parameters, and blood metabolites in dairy calves.
results_summary: Supplementation with 2 g/d of PPA improved average daily gain, final body weight, and intake of starter and milk + milk replacer, without adverse effects on health parameters or blood metabolites. Higher PPA levels showed mixed effects on blood parameters, such as decreased serum glucose and urea concentrations.
population_specificity: Forty female Holstein calves (43.35 ± 2.41 kg body weight, 25.1 ± 2.2 days of age).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether oral willow bark (WB) could alleviate pain in dairy calves undergoing cautery disbudding, compared to lidocaine or sham disbudding.
results_summary: Neither willow bark nor lidocaine effectively reduced pain in calves post-disbudding, as indicated by elevated heart rates, higher cortisol levels, and altered lying behavior compared to sham disbudding. Ocular temperature was unaffected by treatment.
population_specificity: 42 Holstein and crossbred heifer calves aged 4-7 weeks.
effective_dosage: 200 mg/kg of willow bark (single oral bolus).
study_duration: Observations were made for 5 hours post-disbudding, with lying behavior monitored for 72 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of lidocaine-infused castration bands (LLB) versus standard bands on behavior, performance, and blood parameters in calves.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in overall body weight, ADG, feed conversion, or clinical illness scores between treatments, but weekly ADG, G:F, lying bouts, stand bout time, and wound licks showed treatment differences. LLB demonstrated positive outcomes in performance and behavior during wound granulation, suggesting improved animal welfare.
population_specificity: 26 male beef-dairy cross calves

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of Trypanosoma vivax infection on Jersey cows, including hematologic, biochemical, and antioxidant responses, and the impact of treatment with isometamidium chloride.
results_summary: Infected cows showed anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, oxidative stress, and liver/muscle damage, but milk production and feed intake were unaffected. Treatment led to a modest increase in milk production (1.72 kg) ten days post-treatment.
population_specificity: Naturally infected Jersey cows (20 cows, 14 seropositive for T. vivax).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of Haemonchus contortus infections in dairy sheep and goats in Greece and evaluate host-related risk factors affecting haemonchosis.
results_summary: The study found a 37.2% prevalence of H. contortus infection in small ruminants, with factors like anthelmintic treatment, age, management system, altitude, and season significantly influencing infection rates in sheep and goats.
population_specificity: Dairy sheep and goats in continental and insular Greece.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify cows with suboptimal fertility and evaluate whether hormonal interventions (Presynch-Ovsynch and Double-Ovsynch) could improve reproductive efficiency in low-fertility dairy cows.
results_summary: The Fertility Index successfully differentiated pregnancy and culling outcomes between high- and low-fertility cows. Double-Ovsynch optimized first-service rates for low-fertility cows but did not improve pregnancy rates compared to Presynch-Ovsynch when cows were allowed estrus insemination during presynchronization.
population_specificity: Dairy cows (first-lactation and second- or greater-lactation) from one herd, classified by a proprietary Fertility Index.
effective_dosage: Not specified (hormonal intervention protocols described but no explicit dosage details).
study_duration: Interventions initiated at 50–75 days in milk (DIM), with follow-up to 250 DIM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of high-intensity ultrasound on probiotic strawberry milk beverages to reduce syneresis and improve sensory properties without compromising probiotic viability.
results_summary: Ultrasound treatment (5-7.5 min) significantly reduced syneresis (by 11-18%) compared to the control, improved sensory properties, and maintained probiotic viability while altering fatty acid composition and reducing sucrose content.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied general consumer acceptance of probiotic milk beverages).
effective_dosage: Ultrasound processing times of 2.5, 5, 7.5, and 10 min at 40% amplitude (acoustic power density of 1.2 W/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate differences in uterine and serum metabolome associated with clinical cure failure of metritis in dairy cows.
results_summary: The study found that clinical cure failure in cows with metritis was linked to differences in uterine metabolome related to carbohydrate, amino acid, and lipid metabolism, suggesting greater tissue lesion and inflammation. No differences were observed in serum metabolome or uterine metabolome by day 5.
population_specificity: Lactating Holstein cows from two Florida dairies diagnosed with metritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (all cows with metritis received antimicrobial therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of low CP diets with legume silages on dairy cow performance, metabolism, and nitrogen use efficiency to reduce feed costs and environmental impact.
results_summary: Reducing dietary CP in legume-based diets decreased DM intake, milk yield, and milk protein but improved nitrogen use efficiency. Including rumen-protected methionine and limiting legume silage proportion mitigated some negative effects.
population_specificity: Dairy cows
effective_dosage: Dietary CP levels reduced from 171 g/kg DM to 145 g/kg DM

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of vitamin D fortification in dairy and other foods on serum levels, intake, and health outcomes, as well as assess stability, bio-accessibility, bioavailability, and cost-effectiveness.
results_summary: Fortifying dairy products effectively increased serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels, with vitamin D3 showing superior efficacy over vitamin D2. Encapsulation techniques improved stability and bioavailability, and fortifying staple foods like milk proved cost-effective compared to pharmaceutical interventions.
population_specificity: Healthy adults from diverse geographic locations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the composition, benefits, and effects of bovine colostrum (BC) on infants, children, and preterm infants, focusing on its role in growth, development, and pediatric diseases.
results_summary: BC shows promise for gut and immune health, with benefits for conditions like NEC, infectious diarrhea, and neonatal sepsis, supported by its anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and immunomodulatory properties. However, potential allergic reactions and the need for precise dosing standards were noted.
population_specificity: General infants, children, and preterm infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of thermal processing in infant milk formula (IMF) on protein digestion and gut barrier health in infants, and to explore alternative processing methods to better mimic human breast milk.
results_summary: The study found that heat treatment in IMF manufacturing alters protein digestion and may impact gut barrier health, with recent efforts focusing on reducing thermal loads to improve these outcomes. The review suggests that alternative processing technologies could help create a safer and more effective IMF.
population_specificity: Infants with immature gut physiology.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of dairy within the Mediterranean diet and its potential effects on inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The study suggests that dairy, as part of the Mediterranean diet, is moderately consumed and may contribute to IBD management, though specific mechanisms remain under investigation. Clinical evidence for dairy's benefits in IBD is limited, with most support coming from preclinical models.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the state-of-the-art research on probiotic foods, including dairy, focusing on their health benefits and the impact of environmental stresses on probiotic functionality.
results_summary: The study summarized the beneficial impacts of probiotic dairy products on human health, identified stress factors affecting probiotic efficacy, and outlined strategies to improve stress tolerance and enhance probiotic applications.
population_specificity: General human health (not specified further)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the relationship between ceramides and disease pathogenesis, focusing on dietary interventions, including dairy restriction, as a strategy to lower circulating ceramide levels.
results_summary: The study found that dietary interventions, including restriction of dairy product consumption, have beneficial effects on modulating ceramide levels, which are associated with various pathological conditions. However, the abstract does not provide specific data on the magnitude of dairy's effect compared to other interventions.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review lactose intolerance and similar gastrointestinal conditions related to dairy consumption.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings but highlights the importance of differentiating lactose intolerance from other GI conditions with similar presentations.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the Cow Pain Scale (CPS) for detecting pain behaviors in stationary dairy cows with mild to moderate lameness and investigate associations between CPS items and orthopedic disease.
results_summary: The study found a significant positive correlation between CPS total scores and lameness scores, indicating CPS is a reliable tool for video pain assessment in dairy cows with orthopedic pain. Behavioral patterns varied among lame cows, suggesting single CPS items should be interpreted cautiously.
population_specificity: 36 clinical lameness cases from 34 individual dairy cows in a loose-housing system.
study_duration: Each lameness case included 2 trials (initial and follow-up), with blinded assessments 3 weeks apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of melatonin supplementation on heart rate variability, oxidative stress, systemic inflammation, and sleep in multiple sclerosis patients.
results_summary: The study compared melatonin supplementation (3 mg/night) to placebo over 12 weeks, measuring changes in HRV, oxidative stress biomarkers, vitamin D levels, and sleep quality, but specific results regarding Dairy were not mentioned in the abstract.
population_specificity: Multiple sclerosis patients (n=27, with 15 in the melatonin group and 12 in the placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of dairy-derived bioactive peptides in lowering uric acid levels and inhibiting xanthine oxidase (XOD) as a natural approach to managing hyperuricemia (HUA).
results_summary: The study highlighted that dairy products contain bioactive substances with effective antihyperuricemia and XOD inhibitory properties, suggesting their potential as natural alternatives to pharmacological treatments for HUA. However, specific efficacy data or clinical outcomes related to dairy were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to advocate for the health benefits and cultural importance of cultured milk products, focusing on their therapeutic potential and applications in managing cardiometabolic diseases.
results_summary: The study found that cultured milk products, such as yogurt and lassi, have scientifically proven benefits including immune system strengthening, anti-mutagenic effects, suitability for lactose-intolerant individuals, and protection against cancer, osteoporosis, and gut disorders. These products are also highly valued in managing cardiometabolic diseases like hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and obesity.
population_specificity: General human population, with a focus on South Asian cuisine consumers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-protein versus low-protein breakfasts on body composition and cardiometabolic markers in young women with overweight.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the high-protein breakfast on body composition or cardiometabolic markers.
population_specificity: Young women aged 18-30 years with overweight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current epidemiological landscape of HPAI A(H5N1) in US dairy cows and its interspecies transmission, including viral determinants, host range, and vaccination strategies.
results_summary: The study found that HPAI A(H5N1) has spread to 299 dairy herds across 14 US states, causing symptoms like reduced appetite, fever, and sudden milk production drops, with transmission possible through raw milk. It also highlighted the virus's ability to infect unconventional hosts, including cattle, challenging previous assumptions.
population_specificity: Dairy cows in the US and other mammalian hosts globally.
